With March Madness behind us, the betting world is ready for Augusta, and that means examining the **2021 Masters odds** from two perspectives. The sportsbooks and our Golf Model. Our Model, which we go into more detail on down the bottom, was developed by one of the sharpest sports betting data scientists in the world. In this article, we'll share: * Who suits Augusta * The Masters Odds * The Predictions from our PGA Model * Where the betting value is * Who we're backing to win the 2021 Masters * What props we're betting on too All your betting needs are covered, using the most up to date data sources and a sharp betting model. - - - ## **Augusta Angles** Before we share the models picks, here's the Course Fit Tool from DataGolf to remind you who suits Augusta: ![the masters odds course fit tool](/images/uploads/screen-shot-2021-03-12-at-3.14.22-pm.png "the masters odds course fit tool") When you put the relative importance filter on, you're asking for a strong short game, good irons, and big driving. Basically the total package. But you can see that if you're off with the stick and the wedge, you won't be wearing green on Sunday. - - - ## **2021 Masters Odds** As you'll soon see, odds are everything. We look for value when we bet. Which is players that are much shorter on our Golf Model than the sportsbooks. The greater the difference in odds, the better the bet. What stands out at The Masters, is that sportsbooks opinions vary. And if you shop around for the top odds, you can make a case to back multiple players at great odds. We'll share those shortly, but take a look at the Top 16 players, and how their odds vary: ![masters odds 2021](/images/uploads/masters-odds-2021.png "masters odds 2021") Why 16 players? Well, we were tight for room, and wanted to include Webb Simpson. We recommended Webb at 40-1 weeks ago and you can still see the same odds. - - - ## **2021 Masters Predictions** Finally, let's examine the predictions from our Golf Model:
So where is the value this week? Well we compare it to [Odds Boom](https://www.oddsboom.com/golf/futures/1990-masters/) for the US sportsbook prices. - - -

- - - ## **2021 Masters Picks** As you can see from the outputs, the Model has Jon Rahm on top. Narrowly ahead of the defending champion, **Dustin Johnson**. First thing to note, the Model doesn't realise that big Roger Rahmjet had a kid this week. Now, will he play with the freedom of a man with higher priorities or will he play like a sleep deprived foreign father away from his wife and son? Caesars is betting the latter as they have him the best odds in the world, at +1400. That's a bet according to our Model. But we're going to dangerously leave Rahm out and focus on the other opportunities. As you may ave noticed, the Model doesn't quote rate DJ as high as the sportsbooks. And the Model isn't buying **Speeeeef** tickets, despite the incredible comeback form. **Bryson and JT**, are similarly under the odds. The Model, as usual, loves the look of some familiar names. **Xander Schauffele**, **Patrick Cantlay** and **Webb Simpson**. Painfully, it found similar blokes last year. But we ride or die with the Model. Developed by one of the sharpest sports betting data scientists on the planet, we stay true. Lets examine the full list of players that are over the market odds and provide value bets: * Jon Rahm (11-1 Model, 14-1 Market) * **Xander Schauffele (21-1 Model, 26-1 Market)** * Patrick Cantlay (21-1 Model, 22-1 Market) * **Webb Simpson (24-1 Model, 40-1 Market)** * - - - ## **Final 2021 Masters Picks** Coming soon. - - -

- - - ## **2020 Masters Picks** We didn't find DJ. Dammit. Here are the five men we circled. Plus we had some prop bets which did ok, but in total, a losing event. (our 1 unit is $100) * **Xander Schaufelle** to win at 15-1 for 2 units * **Webb Simpson** to win at 33-1 for 1 unit * **Patrick Cantlay** to win at 28-1 or higher for 1 unit * **Matt Kuchar** to win at 170-1 for 0.3 units * **Gary Woodland** to win at 170-1 for 0.3 units. - - - ## **Why Should I Care About Your Model?** Glad you asked. Firstly, our chief data scientist is no joke. He makes a healthy living by betting off his sports models. His most recent, our golf model, uses the last 15 years of data to produce win predictions for PGA tournaments. The model can be broken down into three stages: 1. **Historic score adjustment** Firstly, historic golf scores are adjusted to account for varying course difficulty and conditions on the day. For example a "-2" on a certain course/day combination may be an average score but on another course/day combination it might be a great score due to the course being more difficult and/or unfavorable conditions. This adjustment is necessary so that we can compare players on a like for like basis. 2. **Score prediction** We then create features using the adjusted historic scores and run a few machine learning algorithms on top of these, weighting each equally. These provide an accurate prediction for the most likely score that a player will achieve on an average course in the future. 3. **Simulation** Using these future score predictions, for a given tournament we can then simulate each player's score using their own score distribution to come up with win percentages and fair odds for each player in a tournament. - - - ## **More Golf Betting Expertise** If you love betting on golf like us, check out our **[Top 50 World Golf Rankings](https://www.betrefinery.com/golf-betting/world-golf-rankings)**. We update them every week. Plus we have a **[How To Bet On Golf Guide](https://www.betrefinery.com/golf-betting/how-to-bet-on-golf)** that we think you'll love too. Whilst we might play off 22 when we go around the course, our golf betting is off scratch.
